page.title: 19MITCHELDEAN MARKET
page.content: The tiny Mitcheldean Town Hall built in 1710, and at present used for exhibitions and Parish Council meetings, was originally a market hall. Mitcheldean was well placed for exchange of goods between the Forest mining communities to the west, and the farming country to the east and north. In common with other small market towns, improved roads and transport led to decline in favour of the larger more distant markets. The corn market never really recovered from the riots of 1795, when starving miners attacked loads of corn on their way to Gloucester docks for transporting overseas to feed troops. Later, according to local people, the meat market suffered from a belief that the flies on the meat had previously been feeding on rotting corpses hanging from local gallows!
